awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Efficient Methods for Identifiability of Dynamic Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the project is to analyze and improve the calibration of dynamic models developed by researchers in biology and other sciences to model real-world processes. Mathematical models are used broadly across biology to understand mechanisms, make predictions, and guide intervention strategies. To do so, the model parameters often must be calibrated using data; the estimated parameters can have significant implications for reliability of insights generated from the model and data. This raises the important question of whether the calibration process is well posed, i.e. is it possible to uniquely estimate model parameters from a given type or set of data? Identifiability analysis is the study of these issues, and this project will improve and expand the currently available set of algebraic identifiability methods to set them on a firmer theoretical basis and address new types of models used broadly in many biological settings. Beyond academia, the algorithms to be developed will allow researchers to successfully link models and experiments to generate model-based insights that improve real-world treatment strategies. Training will be provided to two Ph.D. students working on research for this project. The training component will also include interdisciplinary course development as well as a conference with tutorial lectures and problem sessions to educate industrial and academic participants in the theory, algorithms, and software developed in this project.  This project is supported jointly by the Division of Mathematical Sciences Mathematical Biology and Division of Computing and Communication Foundations Algorithmic Foundations programs.

More specifically, the investigators will develop, analyze, and implement symbolic and symbolic-numeric algorithms that perform identifiability analysis of dynamic models (including ordinary differential (ODE), delay, and difference equation models) that appear in biology and other sciences. Using these algorithms, they will also carry out identifiability analysis for a range of models drawn from cellular signaling and physiology applications. The proposed algorithms will be based on differential-difference algebra, which connects to identifiability in the common case of rational ODEs/delay/difference equations by applying differential-difference elimination algorithms to the model equations. Such symbolic methods for ODE models have proven to be productive in the area of parameter identifiability. The proposed methods would allow a large class of models to be analyzed for structural identifiability, allowing one to assess which parameters can be estimated and tailor experiment design to answer the questions of interest for treatment strategies and mechanistic insights. For the first time, rigorously justified and analyzed efficient algorithms will be available for identifiability problems in delay and difference equation models. Certified and more efficient algorithms will appear for global identifiability problems in ODE models. To carry out the proposed research, new advances in the algebraic theory of differential/difference equations will be made.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Understanding and assessing uncertainty is a critical part of any applied modeling work, and a clear understanding of the inferences one is making (and what inferences are possible) is critical to applications, especially those informing policy and decision-making. This project developed new mathematical and computational methods to address identifiability and uncertainty for problems in biology and health and help to elucidate what inferences are possible (or not) from particular models and data. 

 

One major outcome were methods for assessing and handling identifiability and uncertainty in models of COVID-19, in collaboration with the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services. These questions were particularly important because of the novel nature of the pathogen and the time-varying nature of testing capacity and sheltering/social distancing interventions. We developed a hybrid sampling-estimation approach that allowed us to create accurate projections of future incidence accompanied by realistic estimates of the uncertainty in those projections.

 

A second major outcome was the application of the hybrid sampling-estimation approach to models of randomized controlled trials of water, sanitation, and hygiene interventions, in collaboration with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Observed trial outcomes could be a result of different combinations of contextual factors, such as disease prevalence and water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions, and intervention factors, including efficacy, coverage, and compliance. We accounted for this uncertainty in estimating the potential impact of different intervention strategies.

 

A third major outcome was the development of identifiable pharmacokinetic models of breath tests for identifying gut dysfunction, in collaboration with the International Atomic Energy Agency. We determined which breath test curve dynamics were associated with different aspects of sucrose metabolism, and we proposed a model-based diagnostic to determine whether an individual had disrupted sucrose metabolism.

 

Finally, as part of this work, identifiability results were established for several broad classes of models, including partial differential equation age and time dependent disease transmission models, models driven by input forcing functions, and spatially resolved gridded transmission models.

 


Last Modified: 09/09/2024
Modified by: Marisa C Eisenberg

    Andrew Brouwer and Marisa Eisenberg
    Creative Commons
    Marisa C Eisenberg
    COVID-19 modeling forecasts
  • A mechanistic model of breath curves. We leveraged experimental 13C-sucrose breath test curves and a mechanistic pharmacokinetic model, using parameter identifiability and estimation to connect changes in breath test curves to underlying metabolic processes.
    Andrew Brouwer
    Creative Commons
    Marisa C Eisenberg
    A mechanistic model of breath curves
  • When coverage is low and compliance is high, it is easier to increase intervention effectiveness by increasing coverage, but when coverage is higher and compliance is low, then it is easier to increase intervention effectiveness by increasing compliance.
    Andrew Brouwer
    Creative Commons
    Marisa C Eisenberg
    Intervention effectiveness as a function of water, sanitation, and hygiene intervention factors.
por.por_txt_cntn:
Understanding and assessing uncertainty is a critical part of any applied modeling work, and a clear understanding of the inferences one is making (and what inferences are possible) is critical to applications, especially those informing policy and decision-making. This project developed new mathematical and computational methods to address identifiability and uncertainty for problems in biology and health and help to elucidate what inferences are possible (or not) from particular models and data.





One major outcome were methods for assessing and handling identifiability and uncertainty in models of COVID-19, in collaboration with the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services. These questions were particularly important because of the novel nature of the pathogen and the time-varying nature of testing capacity and sheltering/social distancing interventions. Finally, as part of this work, identifiability results were established for several broad classes of models, including partial differential equation age and time dependent disease transmission models, models driven by input forcing functions, and spatially resolved gridded transmission models.
